<description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter including introduction and glossary omitted.<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:<lb/>Source texts incomplete</description>
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.

VI. THE ARMOURERS. THE ORIGENALL PERTEYNYNG TO ÃE CRAFTE OF ARMOURERS. Adam and Eve driven from Eden. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Angelus. Adam. Eue.]

1. Ang. Alle creatures to me take tent, Fro god of heuen now am I sent Vnto Ã¾e wrecchis Ã¾at wronge has went thaymself to woo, Ãe joie of heuen Ã¾at thaym was lent is lost thaym froo. 2. Fro thaym is loste boÃ¾e game and glee, He badde Ã¾at Ã¾ei schuld maistirs be Ouer alle-kynne thyng, oute-tane a tree he taught Ã¾em tille; And Ã¾er-to wente bothe she and he, agayne his wille. 3. Agaynst his wille Ã¾us haue they wrought, To greeffe grete god gaffe they right noght, Ã¾at wele wytt ye; And therfore syte is to Ã¾aym sought; as ye shalle see. 4. The fooles Ã¾at faithe is fallen fra, Take tente to me nowe, or ye ga; Fro god of heuen vnto yow twa sente am I nowe, For to warne you what-kynne wa is wrought for you. 5. Adam. For vs is wrought, so welaway! Doole endurand nyghte and day, The welthe we wende haue wonnyd in ay is loste vs fra. For this myscheffe ful wele we may euer mornyng ma. 6. Ang. Adam, Ã¾y selffe made al Ã¾is syte, For to the tree Ã¾ou wente full tyte, And boldely on the frute gan byte my lord for-bed. Adam. Yaa, allas! my wiffe Ã¾at may I wite, for scho me red. 7. Ang. Adam, for Ã¾ou trowyd hir tale, He sendis Ã¾e worde and sais Ã¾ou shale lyffe ay in sorowe, Abide and be in bittir bale, tille he Ã¾e borowe. 8. Ad. Allas! wrecchis, what haue we wrought, To byggly blys we bothe wer brought, whillis we wer Ã¾are We hadde i-nowe, nowe haue we noghte, allas! for care. 9. Eua. Oure cares ar comen bothe kyne and colde, With fele fandyngis many folde, Allas! Ã¾at tyraunte to me tolde, thurghoute his gyle, That we shulde haue alle welthis in walde, wa worthe Ã¾e whyle! 10. Ang. That while ye wrought vnwittely, Soo for to greue god almighty, And Ã¾at mon ye full dere abye or Ã¾at ye go. And to lyffe, as is worthy, in were and wo. 11. Adam! haue Ã¾is, luke howe ye thynke, And tille with-alle Ã¾i meete and drynke for euer-more. Adam. Allas! for syte why myght y synke, so shames me sore. 12. Eue. Soore may we shame with sorowes seere, And felly fare we bothe in feere, Allas! Ã¾at euyr we neghed it nere, Ã¾at tree vn-till. With dole now mon we bye full dere, oure dedis ille. 13. Ang. Giffe, for Ã¾ou beswyked hym swa, Trauell herto shalle Ã¾ou ta, Thy barnes to bere with mekill wa Ã¾is warne I Ã¾e. Buxom shalle Ã¾ou and othir ma to man ay be. 14. Eue. Allas! for doole what shall y doo, Now mon I neuer haue rest ne roo. Adam. Nay, lo! swilke a tale is taken me too, to trauyalle tyte, Nowe is shente both I and shoo, allas! for syte. 15. Allas! for syte and sorowe sadde, Mournynge makis me mased and madde, To thynke in herte what helpe y hadde, and nowe has none. On grounde mon I neuyr goo gladde, my gamys ere gane. 16. Gone ar my games with-owten glee, Allas! in blisse kouthe we no?t bee, For putte we were to grete plente at prime of Ã¾e day; Be tyme of none alle lost had wee, sa welawaye. 17. Sa welaway! for harde peyne, Alle bestis were to my biddyng bayne, Fisshe and fowle, they were fulle fayne with me to founde. And nowe is alle thynge me agayne, Ã¾at gois on grounde. 18. On grounde ongaynely may y gange, To suffre syte and peynes strange, Alle is for dede I haue done wrange Thurgh wykkid wyle. On-lyve me thynkith I lyffe to lange, allas! Ã¾e whille. 19. A! lord, I thynke what thynge is Ã¾is, That me is ordayned for my mysse, Gyffe I wirke wronge, whom should me wys be any waye? How beste wille be, so haue y blisse, I shalle assaye. 20. Allas! for bale, what may Ã¾is bee, In worlde vnwisely wrought haue wee, This erthe it trembelys for this tree, and dyns ilk dele. Alle Ã¾is worlde is wroth with mee, Ã¾is wote I wele. 21. Full wele y wote my welthe is gone, Erthe, elementis, euer ilkane, For my synne has sorowe tane, Ã¾is wele I see. Was neuere wrecchis so wylle of wane as nowe ar wee. 22. Eue. We are fulle wele worthy i-wis To haue Ã¾is myscheffe for oure mys, For broght we were to byggely blys, euer in to be. Nowe my sadde sorowe certis is Ã¾is, my silfe to see. 23. Ad. To see it is a sytfull syghte, We bothe Ã¾at were in blis so brighte, We mon go nakid euery-ilke a nyght, and dayes by-dene. Allas! what womans witte was light! Ã¾at was wele sene. 24. Eue. Sethyn it was so me knyth it sore, Bot sythen that woman witteles ware, Mans maistrie shulde haue bene more agayns Ã¾e gilte. Ad. Nay, at my speche wolde Ã¾ou never spare, Ã¾at has vs spilte. 25. Eue. Iff I hadde spoken youe oughte to spill, Ye shulde haue taken gode tent Ã¾ere tyll, and turnyd my Ã¾ought. Ad. Do way, woman, and neme it nought, 26. For at my biddyng wolde Ã¾ou not be, And therfore my woo wyte y thee, Thurgh ille counsaille Ã¾us casten ar we, in bittir bale. Nowe god late never man aftir me triste woman tale. 27. For certis me rewes fulle sare, That euere I shulde lerne at Ã¾i lare, Thy counsaille has casten me in care, Ã¾at Ã¾ou me kende. Eue. Be stille Adam, and nemen it na mare, it may not mende. 28. For wele I wate I haue done wrange, And therfore euere I morne emange, Allas! the whille I leue so lange, dede wolde I be! Ad. On grounde mon I never gladde gange, withowten glee. 29. Withowten glee I ga, This sorowe wille me sla, This tree vn-to me wille I ta, Ã¾at me is sende. He Ã¾at vs wrought wisse vs fro wa, whare-som we wende. Finis.
